I think I might have witnessed a bug for the defautl `.yaml` config of `pre-commit` details below. 
## The problem
```
putup --pre-commit example
```
results in a `.pre-commit-config.yaml` file with the following content: 

```yaml
exclude: '^docs/conf.py'

repos:
- repo: git://github.com/pre-commit/pre-commit-hooks
  rev: v2.2.3 # "BUG": v3.1.0 would be the latest one
```

items.body:
After the discussion in #242, it is evident that Windows support is important for PyScaffold.
#243 address this topic by adding automated tests on Windows via Cirrus CI. However, as indicated in one of the [Cirrus CI builds](https://cirrus-ci.com/task/5836154039959552), some tests are still failing on Windows (despite of a huge effort I put into debugging it 😢)

- [test_info.py:19](https://cirrus-ci.com/task/5836154039959552?command=test#L632) error seems to be just silly, and I don't understand why it is happening.
  According to [Python docs](https://docs.python.org/3.5/library/getpass.html), if `USERNAME` is set, we shouldn't be seeing this error... But we are.
  This is not super important since the user is supposed to configure git anyway...
  So I am wondering, should we skip this test on Windows using PyTest marks?

- [test_repo.py:74](https://cirrus-ci.com/task/5836154039959552?command=test#L1299) error is enigmatic...
  I have 0 clues why we don't have access rights to the git repository.
  If we can create the folder, we should be able to remove it...
  But again, it might not be super important... Looks like it is a super specific sequence of actions in the CI env that is causing that...

- [test_install.py:123](https://cirrus-ci.com/task/5836154039959552?command=test#L3980) error is laughable...
  `The filename or extension is too long` is a very poor error message for the fact that Microsoft hardcoded a 260 char limit for file names and never bothered correcting it...
  [It doesn't seem to be easy to solve](https://www.howtogeek.com/266621/how-to-make-windows-10-accept-file-paths-over-260-characters/), but yet again not super important.
  It is an issue with the test suite, not necessarily PyScaffold itself.

The remaining error messages seem to be related, at first glance, to #238 (problems with virtualenvs - particularly testing `bdist`s seems to be a recurring pain... to the first time we have problems with that test case).

@FlorianWilhelm do you have any thoughts on this matter, or any approach for dealing with the errors on Windows?

items.title: Lazy contents for `define_structure` / `create_structure`

labels.name: needs discussion
labels.description: This topic should be discussed further

items.body:
Right now, PyScaffold keeps an in-memory representation of the entire project structure, and all the associated files, which is not very efficient. Moreover, if we check the [`structure.py`](https://github.com/pyscaffold/pyscaffold/blob/master/src/pyscaffold/structure.py), we can see that calling a function with `opts` as an argument is the de-facto standard.

### Proposal
We can accept a function in the dictionary representation. Therefore, any of the following would be accepted:

```python
struct = {
'file1': function,
'file2': (function, metadata),
}
```

#### Function Signature
For the sake of completeness and to avoid future change of the APIs, I believe the following signature is very complete and allows for max flexibility:

```python
def <function_name>(path, opts, previous_content=None):
    """Generate contents for a file in the project structure

    Arguments:
        path(os.PathLike): where the generated contents will be written to
        opts(dict): PyScaffold's options
        previous_content(str): if an existing file exists, the contents of that file will be passed, otherwise ``None``.
    Returns:
        str: Contents that will be written by PyScaffold on ``path``
    """
```

This enables a series of new scenarios like:
- appending contents to existing files
- removing sections of existing files
...

**O.B.S.:** Requires structure manipulation helpers to be updated accordingly (with potential changes in API).

#### Backward Compatibility
This change can be done in a disruptive way by enforcing functions (and therefore take advantage of the 4.0 release #235 to change the APIs/docs), or in a backward-compatible way by accepting all the following forms:
```python
structure = {
'file1': function,
'file2': 'string',
'file3': (function, metadata),
'file4': ('string', metadata),
}
```
We already loop through all the components, normalizing `'string'` to `('string', None)`, we can easily do the same, normalizing `function` to `(function, None)` and `('string', None)` to:
```python
(lambda *_, **__: 'string', None)
```

items.title: Introduce global config
items.body:
Since PyScaffold users probably use `putup` to create new packages in a recurring basis, it would be nice to allow them to "save" their favourite options somewhere.

### Proposal
The `create_project` function could deep merge the arguments coming from the current sources:
1. Global configuration file (or file specified by an `--config PATH` flag)
2. Local `setup.cfg` (or maybe `pyproject.toml` like everyone seems to be doing nowadays?)
3. Given arguments (via cli or direct api call)
(in order)

Additionally a flag `--save-config` could be used in any `putup` invocation to save the given parameters to the global config file (to *bootstrap* the config file creation).

### Global Config File:
Something following what PyScaffold already does with per-project `setup.cfg`, but in a global location:
- *OSX*: `~/Library/Preferences/pyscaffold/default.cfg` (or something like that)
- *Windows*: `C:\Users\<username>\AppData\Local\pyscaffold\pyscaffold\default.cfg`
- *Linux/Others*: `$XDG_CONFIG_HOME/pyscaffold/default.cfg` with fallback to `~/.config/pyscaffold/default.cfg`

items.title: Inconsistent project name when updating

milestone.title: v4.0
milestone.description: Release with major changes like moving some of the core extensions into the official PyScaffold organisation.

items.body:
First of all, this is only an edge case problem. During an update right now we make the basic assumption that the name of the directory holding the project is still the project name. In most cases this will be true but not every time. The problem is that we treat the positional argument during an update as project name but in reality it is only the directory holding the project. The actual project name is saved within setup.cfg. To solve this edge case we need to differentiate between those two concepts. This is closely related to issue #138 which can only be cleanly resolved if we differentiate between project directory and project name.

My suggestion for version 4.0 would be following API change. The positional PROJECT argument of putup will be renamed into PATH thus specifying the directory for the project. An additional optional `--project` argument specifies the actual project name. If the project name is not provided the last path element of PATH is used. Thus for most users the behaviour will not change but we have a clear separation between project directory and project name.

items.title: Move entry_points and setup_requires to setup.cfg
items.body: Version 3.0 of PyScaffold still has two parameters (`entry_points` and `setup_requires`) in `setup.py` instead of `setup.cfg` due to historical reasons and limitations of `setuptools` at that point. It seems now possible according to this [stackoverflow question](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/48884796/how-to-setup-entry-points-in-setup-cfg). We should thus make use of this possibility in PyScaffold version 3.1 and also move `setup_requires` to `setup.cfg` to completely get rid of any configuration in `setup.py` with the exception of Cython extensions. These will hopefully be supported in future `setuptools` version by some syntax in `setup.cfg`.

items.title: __author__ / __copyright__ / __license__ not widely accepted as modern best practice
items.body:
I was a bit surprised by the presence of `__author__`, `__copyright__`, and `__license__` being introduced to my project by PyScaffold, so I did a quick bit of googling to try to find whether there was any generally accepted wisdom about whether they should or shouldn't be used.  Most of the results seemed to reference pretty old style guides, e.g.

- http://web.archive.org/web/20111010053227/http://jaynes.colorado.edu/PythonGuidelines.html#module_formatting
- http://epydoc.sourceforge.net/manual-fields.html#module-metadata-variables (does *anyone* use epydoc these days?)

 I couldn't find *any* recent documents advising the use of these.  In contrast, look at the comments below [this answer to "What is the common header format of Python files?" on Stack Overflow](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/1523427/what-is-the-common-header-format-of-python-files/1523456#1523456).  Whilst the answer itself got a lot of votes simply by being helpfully factual without stating any opinion on best practice, by far the most upvoted comment was:

> I think all of this metadata after the imports is a bad idea. The parts of this metadata that apply to a single file (eg author, date) are already tracked by source control. Putting an erroneous & out of date copy of the same info in the file itself seems wrong to me. The parts that apply to the whole project (eg licence, versioning) seem better located at a project level, in a file of their own, rather than in every source code file.

And indeed with well-established modern best practices which involve [putting a single license file in the repository at the top level of the repository](https://help.github.com/articles/licensing-a-repository/#determining-the-location-of-your-license), and tracking authorship via git, these variables seem pretty anachronistic, in addition to violating the widely agreed-on [DRY principle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Don%27t_repeat_yourself).  So I suggest removing them.

items.title: clean up imports in __init__.py
items.body:
Currently in the `__init__.py ` file there are two names imported from `setuptools`. These names should probably be `del`ed before the module finishes running to clean up the package's namespace.

For example:

```python
# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-
from pkg_resources import get_distribution, DistributionNotFound

try:
    # Change here if project is renamed and does not equal the package name
    dist_name = 'test-pscf-proj'
    __version__ = get_distribution(dist_name).version
except DistributionNotFound:
    __version__ = 'unknown'
finally:
    del get_distribution, DistributionNotFound
```

This is because if anyone runs `from myproj import *`, they're going to get `get_distribution` and `DistributionNotFound` into their module namespace as well.

By the way, looking at this file, the `dist_name` can probably be replaced with `__name__` which removes the need to explicitly spell it out in the `__init__` file.

Also, is `'unknown'` an appropriate value here? it's not a valid PEP440 version string if i understand correctly. Maybe `None` is more appropriate? I'm not sure what's the right thing to do here but `'unknown'` smells wrong to me.
